Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The genomics of adaptation in experimental yeast populations during short and long-term selection on invasive growth
Award.AbstractNarration:
How populations change genetically and adapt to environmental conditions is a fundamental issue in evolutionary biology, plant and animal breeding, and disease. Such genetic changes occur on two time scales. In the short term, selection acts on existing genetic variation. On longer time scales, adaptation requires the input and selection of new mutations. New genome-sequencing technologies make it possible to observe directly the genome-wide genetic changes that occur during response to novel environmental conditions. The project will study the genetic basis of adaptation during selection for invasive growth, a trait that is an important aspect of fungal virulence, in populations of the model microbe Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker's yeast). New technologies for sequencing and analyzing genomes will be used to identify loci that contribute to variation for invasive growth, to study changes in allele frequencies, and to identify novel mutations that occur during selection.

This study will provide new information about how genome-wide genetic composition both influences and is influenced by evolution in controlled, reproducible experiments that focus on a fungal trait that is ecologically important and related to emergence of pathogenicity. This project will furnish an excellent case study for public education on evolution, the interactions between random and predictable processes in evolution, and the direct relevance of evolution to human health. Research and outreach activities will provide interdisciplinary and quantitative training opportunities in laboratory experimentation, population genetics, genomics, and bioinformatics for graduate students, undergraduates, and high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to study the process of adaptation in populations of Saccharomyces cerevisiae (budding yeast), by employing a combination of quantitative genetics, experimental evolution, and whole-genome sequencing.  Key aims of the project were to: 1) identify loci that contribute variation in yeast invasive growth, a complex trait that is both ecologically and medically relevant; 2) to determine whether responses to short-term selection can be predicted  from knowledge about the genetic architecture of complex traits; and 3) to characterize novel mutations that affect invasive growth that arise during the course of long-term evolution.

Intellectual Merit: The investigators used a technique called quantitative trait locus (QTL) mapping to identify regions of the genome (loci) and DNA changes (alleles) that contribute to differences in invasive growth between different genetic backgrounds of yeast.   The investigators subsequently used experimental evolution techniques to identify genomic regions that respond to selection for invasive growth.  They found that the process of adaptation was highly repeatable for a given starting population. However, the outcomes of selection can differ substantially between different starting populations, even when those starting populations are derived from the same genetic backgrounds. Knowledge of genetic architecture, as inferred from QTL mapping, was found to have modest power to predict the outcomes of short-term selection.  The results of this project help to answer fundamental questions about how genetic architecture both influences and is influenced by adaptation. The outcomes also contribute to a better understanding of the gene networks that control invasive growth, and advances the field of experimental evolution by showing how standing variation and novel mutations can be monitored over the course of evolution using high-throughput sequencing.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of the project included the support and training of several undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar.  Participants at all levels of training learned cutting edge methods in yeast genetics, genomics and bioinformatics and applied their knowledge to the study of the fundamental processes of evolution. The investigators also developed and ran a yearly one-week scientific outreach course at a public high school (North Carolina School for Science and Math). This outreach effort introduced students to concepts from genetics, microbiology, and evolutionary biology.  Several high school students who took this "mini-term" course subsequently participated in summer research experiences at Duke University.
